translation1: "Is tire choice when cycling really as safe as advertised? This morning, I woke up full of determination, wanting to at least train a little for my upcoming cycling tour next week. Well, I did it and I rode my racing bike, which I bought on eBay yesterday.The first 40km were really nice - but then what always lurks in every city center (this time: thank you Krefeld!) happened. Glass splinters on the route. Zack, loud hissing and my rear tire didn't want to continue the rest of the route on no account.Because of the day of the week, I didn't have a real opportunity to get a spare jacket and spare tube, so I had to turn around with somewhat bad mood and take the first train home. It wasn't technically that bad, maybe it's better if I practice the tire change before the bike ride again. But now I'm facing a question and hoping that you can help me.Since I have a relatively long distance to cover over several days, I would be very unhappy to encounter this problem frequently. Now it wasn't really bad, as the old tires from the previous owner (a very nice old man who had 140km on them when I picked up the bike at 10:12 am!) were already considered suboptimal, as he had been riding on them for several years. However, when I think about having to change a tire after 80-90km of riding, I think I'll be in a pretty bad mood: :DNow I have come into conversation with an older man at the platform about why I don't have the Marathon Plus tires; these are supposed to be unrepairable. Of course, that all sounds very tempting. But are they really that indestructible?I have little desire to spend 40€/tire right now, only to be disappointed. Furthermore, I ask myself: when I was on the racing bike, I believed I had 25x622. Although it is also available (apparently) at the Marathon Plus tires, the majority is already wider.Is this a problem? Or would you generally recommend other tires to me for a racing bike? The Schwalbe side seems to be my absolute favorite! I have more knowledge about the Durano DD.  Translation:  Is this a problem? Or would you generally recommend other tires to me for a racing bike? This morning I woke up with a fiery drive because I still wanted to at least train a bit in the upcoming weeks in preparation for my upcoming bicycle tour. It was as easy as that and I drove my road bike which I had bought on eBay the day before. The first 40 km were really beautiful - but then that happened which is always waiting for you in the intercity (this time: thanks goes to Krefeld!). Glass shards on the road. Pop, a loud hiss and my back tire was no longer up for riding the rest of the trip. Because of it being a work day, I didn’t really have the chance to acquire a spare tire and tube, I had to turn back halfway through in a bad mood and take the next workable train back home. It was not the worst downer ever, maybe it is even better if I practice changing tires one more time before I leave to go on the tour. But now I am posed with a question and hope that you will be able to help me. Because I have a relatively long stretch of road and many days in front of me, I would very much like to not run into this problem on a regular basis. But if I think about having to change tires every 80-90 km on the tour, then I am already in a really bad mood :D I just got into a discussion with an older man at the train platform, who asked me quite surprised, why I don’t have the Marathon Plus tires, these are supposed to be impossible to pop. Now that certainly does sound tempting. But are they really so indestructible? I have no desire to give out €40 per tire in order to just be disappointed. At the same time, I ask myself: I am using 25x622 race tires at the moment, I believe. This is (apparently?) just like the Marathon Plus tires, but the majority of tires are actually wider. Is that the real problem? Or would you recommend that I really get different tires in general for the road bike? The Schwalbe website seems to be of one opinion! Would common sense tend to recommend the Durano DD? Thank you in advance for your help and take care!

translation1: "\"Party, that we wanted to spit on\": Frankfurt celebrates after a thrilling comeback against Leverkusen. What a spectacular reaction from Eintracht Frankfurt. After 22 minutes, the last twice champions of Germany seemed to be on their way to the next Bundesliga relegation.But then the SGE turned around, shot itself within an hour of frustration over a disappointing start of the season and won fiercely with 5:2. \"It's crazy what the guys have accomplished today,\" coach Oliver Glasner celebrated with DAZN and praised \"a collective effort, to everyone who was involved.\" It initially looked like another setback for the still ninth-placed Frankfurt. Patrik Schick had put Leverkusen in the lead with 2:0.What happened then also impressed the SGE coach. \"As the players returned and showed a fantastic performance,\" Glasner continued. I am crazy happy with the performance we showed and of course with the result.Even defensive player Christopher Lenz, who was able to return to the field for the first time since the fourth game and overcome his muscle injury, emphasized the morale of his teammates. \"I think our mentality is incredible,\" said the 27-year-old and particularly enjoyed the result for the spectators. That was the party we wanted to throw today.For the upcoming tasks, Glasner wants to keep the focus on himself, but sees himself well positioned in terms of the personnel situation. It is extraordinary that all players are fit in December and all players are physically in top condition. It is top work in our medical department, but the players also live highly professionally.Now we want to \"move forward step by step and stay humble\" and complete the tasks until the end of the year \"at this level\". Next up is already on Wednesday as part of the English week, an away game at Borussia Mönchengladbach (7:30 PM, Sky)."

After 22 minutes, the team from Hessen, which had recently lost twice in a row, seemed to be on its way to its next soccer failure. But then the SGE turned themselves around and were able to shoot the frustration of a poor start to the season out of their soul within an hour, leading to a furious 5-2 victory. “It was crazy what the boys were able to accomplish today,” Coach Oliver Glasner said with jubilee at DAZN and spoke of “praise all around, to each and every one of them who were there”. Patrik Schick brought the team from Leverkusen to a 2-0 lead. What happened next deeply effected the SGE coach. “The way the players were able to take it back and display a fantastic performance,” according to Glasner. I am extremely happy with the performance, which we showed and also with the result. It is extraordinary that all of us players are so fit in December, that we are in tip top shape. It is pristine work by our medical department, but our players are also living extremely professionally. reference: The hard “Huidlerer” question: Amberger folk know the answer What is a “Huidlerer”? This regionalism was sent in by someone from Amberg and became a point of serious consideration on the BR TV program “Wir in Bayern”.
